DOC.brief_title: Reducing Hazardous Alcohol Use & Human Immunodeficiency Virus ( HIV ) Viral Load
DOC.detailed_description: This study three-arm randomize controlled trial among hazardous heavy drinking HIV-infected ART clinic client Thai Nguyen province , Vietnam . It compare effect two evidence-based , culturally adapt , behavioral intervention [ Brief Intervention ( BI ) Motivational Enhancement Therapy+Cognitive Behavioral Therapy ( MET+CBT ) Intervention ] compare assessment-only standard care arm , order understand relative effectiveness intervention reduce alcohol use suppress HIV viral load . The Brief Intervention ( BI ) consist 2 individual session 2 booster phone session deliver train counselor base Project Treat . Content BI session include review drinking pattern , harmful effect drinking , alcohol use behavior change strategy . The MET+CBT Intervention consist 6 session deliver trained counselor . The MET+CBT Intervention use client-centered , motivational interviewing approach focus skills-building alcohol use behavior change , include drink refusal skill , skill cope manage craving trigger , develop positive thought attitude . It also include review drinking pattern harmful effect drink . This study also measure incremental cost-effectiveness intervention compare current counseling service offer ART clinic Vietnam . Investigators hypothesize : 1 ) Each intervention effective assessment-only arm percent day alcohol abstinent percent virally suppress 12-month assessment ; 2 ) The BI equivalently effective MET+CBT Intervention percent day alcohol abstinent ; 3 ) The effect intervention alcohol abstinence viral suppression mediate alcohol use readiness change and/or cop skill acquisition ; 4 ) The MET+CBT Intervention effective BI alcohol abstinence viral suppression separately among participant severe alcohol use , people inject drug , participant depressive symptom ; 5 ) The alcohol reduction intervention ( BI MET+CBT Intervention ) highly cost-effective compare assessment-only standard care ; 6 ) The BI highly cost-effective relative MET+CBT Intervention . Understanding relative effectiveness intervention improve alcohol- HIV-related outcome provide insight optimal application alcohol program resource-limited setting .
